questions.text: Post surgery image of a tumor in scrotum is shown below along with its histology. What could be your possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor of the testis, particularly affecting men aged 30-40 years. It is a malignant tumor, but it has a relatively good prognosis and is highly radiosensitive.

Gross Appearance (Post-surgery Image Clues):

  • Well-circumscribed, homogeneous, fleshy, grey-white mass
  • Lacks hemorrhage and necrosis (unlike non-seminomatous tumors)

Histology Features:

  • Large uniform cells with clear cytoplasm (due to glycogen)
  • Prominent central nuclei with distinct nucleoli
  • Arranged in sheets or lobules separated by fibrous septa containing lymphocytic infiltrate
  • Positive for PLAP, c-KIT (CD117), and OCT4

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Teratoma (Option A):

  • Composed of tissues from all three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm)
  • Grossly heterogeneous with cystic, cartilaginous, or tooth-like structures
  • Histology shows diverse mature or immature tissue types (e.g., glandular, neural, muscular)
  • Not typically homogenous or limited to clear cells

Yolk sac tumor (Option C):

  • Most common testicular tumor in children <3 years
  • Histology shows Schiller-Duval bodies (central vessel surrounded by tumor cells resembling glomeruli)
  • AFP positive
  • Grossly more heterogeneous, sometimes with necrosis or hemorrhage

Lymphoma (Option D):

  • Most common testicular tumor in men >60 years
  • Usually bilateral and may infiltrate testis diffusely
  • Histology shows monotonous lymphoid cells
  • Not germ cell origin, and not typical in younger men

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with pulseless disease. On examination, following histopathological finding will be seen:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis is Takayasu arteritis, and the corresponding histopathological finding is Granulomatous vasculitis.

  • The phrase "pulseless disease" is a classic clinical descriptor of Takayasu arteritis, a large-vessel vasculitis that predominantly affects the aorta and its major branches, particularly in young to middle-aged females, but can also occur in males.
  • Involvement of the subclavian arteries can lead to absent or diminished peripheral pulses, giving rise to the term "pulseless disease".
  • Clinical features may include:
    • Asymmetric blood pressure
    • Claudication of the arms
    • Carotidynia
    • Visual or neurologic symptoms
    • Hypertension (due to renal artery involvement)
  • Histopathology typically shows:
    • Granulomatous inflammation of the vessel wall
    • Mononuclear infiltrates (T-cells, macrophages)
    • Multinucleated giant cells
    • Intimal fibrosis and narrowing of the lumen

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Fibrinoid necrosis (Option B): Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in small-vessel vasculitis, especially polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) and microscopic polyangiitis, not in Takayasu arteritis. It is characterized by necrosis of vessel walls with fibrin deposition.

Leukocytoclastic vasculitis (Option C): This refers to hypersensitivity vasculitis involving small vessels, often seen in Henoch-Schonlein purpura (IgA vasculitis). It shows neutrophilic infiltration with nuclear debris (leukocytoclasia), not granulomas.

Thromboangiitis obliterans (Option D): Also known as Buerger disease, this affects small- and medium-sized arteries, especially in young male smokers. Histology shows acute and chronic inflammation with thrombosis, often sparing the internal elastic lamina. It does not present with granulomatous inflammation.

questions.text: On examination of biopsy of a patient diagnosed with Hepatitis B three weeks ago, accumulation of amorphous, basic, proteinaceous material in the vessel wall was seen. This finding is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has a recent history of Hepatitis B infection, and the biopsy reveals accumulation of amorphous, basic (eosinophilic), proteinaceous material in the vessel wall. This description is classic for fibrinoid necrosis.

  • Fibrinoid necrosis is a form of vascular wall injury where there is:
    • Deposition of immune complexes
    • Complement activation
    • Leakage of plasma proteins including fibrin
    • Resulting in an intensely eosinophilic, amorphous appearance of the vessel wall on microscopy
  • This is particularly seen in immune complex-mediated vasculitis, such as polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), which is strongly associated with Hepatitis B virus infection.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Leukocytoclastic vasculitis (Option B): This refers to hypersensitivity vasculitis involving small vessels, with predominant neutrophilic infiltration and nuclear debris (leukocytoclasia). It is not characterized by fibrinoid necrosis and is not typically associated with Hepatitis B.

Hyaline arteriosclerosis (Option C): Seen in chronic hypertension and diabetes, hyaline arteriosclerosis involves homogeneous, pink hyaline thickening of arteriolar walls due to plasma protein leakage and basement membrane production. It is not associated with immune complex vasculitis or Hepatitis B.

Caseous necrosis (Option D): Seen in tuberculosis and certain granulomatous infections, this is a form of cheese-like necrosis found in the center of granulomas, particularly in lungs and lymph nodes, not in vessel walls.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented with following clinical feature. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows characteristic Strawberry gums. The most likely diagnosis is Wegener's granulomatosis, now more accurately called Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA),

  • Wegener's granulomatosis/GPA) shows necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis affecting:
    • Upper respiratory tract (e.g., chronic sinusitis, nasal ulcers, epistaxis)
    • Lower respiratory tract (e.g., cough, hemoptysis, cavitary lung lesions)
    • Kidneys (e.g., rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis)
    • And occasionally skin and eyes.
  • Key laboratory and pathological findings:
    • c-ANCA (PR3-ANCA) positivity (specific for GPA)
    • Necrotizing granulomatous inflammation on biopsy
    • Pulmonary-renal syndrome

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Kawasaki Disease (Option A): Primarily affects children under 5 years old. It is an acute medium-vessel vasculitis, presenting with:

  • Fever ≥5 days
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Strawberry tongue
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Rash
  • Extremity changes

It is not seen in adults and doesn't typically involve granulomatous inflammation or upper airway disease.

Polyarteritis Nodosa-PAN (Option B): Affects medium-sized arteries and is associated with Hepatitis B. It spares the lungs, and presents with systemic features (fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, hypertension, mononeuritis multiplex), but no granulomas, no c-ANCA, and no upper airway involvement.

Microscopic Polyangiitis-Micro PAN (Option C): A small vessel vasculitis like GPA, but without granulomas and without significant upper respiratory tract involvement. It presents with p-ANCA (MPO-ANCA) positivity and can also cause pulmonary-renal syndrome, but lacks the granulomatous inflammation seen in GPA.

questions.text: A patient presented with ulcerative lesions on nasopharynx, nodular lesions with cavitation in the lungs and renal failure. What is the most important investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient presents with the classic triad seen in GPA:

  1. Ulcerative lesions on the nasopharynx-indicating upper respiratory tract involvement
  2. Nodular lesions with cavitation in the lungs-indicating lower respiratory tract involvement
  3. Renal failure-suggesting rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
  • This constellation of findings strongly points toward a necrotizing granulomatous small-vessel vasculitis, particularly GPA.
  • Specifically, c-ANCA (cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody), which targets proteinase 3 (PR3), is the most sensitive and specific marker for GPA.
  • It plays a crucial diagnostic role, especially in patients presenting with this classical triad

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Culture for fungus (Option B): Although fungal infections (e.g., mucormycosis, aspergillosis) can affect the nasopharynx and lungs, they are less likely to involve kidneys in this manner. Also, fungal infections typically do not produce ANCA positivity or granulomatous vasculitis. Culture may be useful in differential diagnosis but is not the most important test in this case.

MDR test for TB (Option C): Pulmonary tuberculosis can produce cavitary lung lesions, but it does not cause ulcerative nasopharyngeal lesions with renal failure. TB is a differential diagnosis but less likely given this presentation. MDR testing is appropriate once TB is suspected, but ANCA testing is more critical here.

All of the above (Option D): While all may be relevant in broad differential diagnosis, only ANCA testing provides a specific diagnostic clue toward GPA in this clinical setting. Hence, not all are equally important, making Option A the best choice.

choices.text: Sudden cardiac death due to Arrhythmia
Sudden cardiac death due to hypertrophy of heart chamber
Sudden cardiac death due to atherosclerosis

questions.text: A 20-year-old athlete suddenly collapsed and died. His case was diagnosed as a Sudden cardiac death. Based on the autopsy image shown below, what is the possible underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sudden collapse and death in a young athlete is a hallmark presentation of Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM).

  • It is a genetic cardiac disorder characterized by:
    • Asymmetric septal hypertrophy
    • Small left ventricular (LV) cavity
    • Myocyte disarray on histology
    • Autosomal dominant inheritance, often with a family history of sudden death
  • This condition predisposes to ventricular arrhythmias, especially during intense physical exertion, leading to sudden cardiac death (SCD).
  • At autopsy, the heart shows:
    • Marked thickening of the interventricular septum
    • Reduced size of the LV cavity
    • Possibly evidence of fibrosis or scarring

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Sudden cardiac death due to Arrhythmia (Option A): While arrhythmia is the terminal event in many sudden cardiac deaths, this option is too vague and nonspecific. The question asks for the underlying cause, which in this case is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy-not just arrhythmia alone.

Valvular heart disease from RHD (Option B): Rheumatic heart disease (RHD) typically causes valvular lesions, especially mitral stenosis or regurgitation, and presents with progressive symptoms, not sudden death during exertion. Also, RHD is rare in athletes and does not commonly cause ventricular arrhythmias in young healthy individuals.

Sudden cardiac death due to atherosclerosis (Option D): Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of sudden cardiac death in older adults, especially those with coronary artery disease. However, it is very unlikely in a 20-year-old without significant risk factors unless there's an unusual condition like familial hypercholesterolemia, which is not mentioned.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents weak pulses in upper limbs, BP 90/60 mm Hg, retinal hemorrhages present, On biopsy, Granulomatous inflammation, replete with giant cells and patchy medial necrosis, is seen. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis in this case is Takayasu Arteritis. Takayasu arteritis classically involves the aortic arch.

  • In a third of patients, it also affects the remainder of the aorta and its branches, with pulmonary artery involvement in half of cases; coronary and renal arteries may be similarly affected.
  • There is irregular thickening of the vessel wall with intimal hyperplasia; when the aortic arch is involved, the great vessel lumens can be markedly narrowed or even obliterated
  • Such narrowing explains the weakness of the peripheral pulses.
  • Histologically the changes range from adventitial mononuclear infiltrates with perivascular cuffing of the vasa vasorum to intense mononuclear inflammation in the media.
  • Granulomatous inflammation, replete with giant cells and patchy medial necrosis, is also seen.
  • The histology is essentially indistinguishable from giant cell (temporal) arteritis.
  • As the disease progresses, collagenous scarring, with admixed chronic inflammatory infiltrates, occurs in all three layers of the vessel wall.
  • Occasionally, aortic root involvement causes dilation and aortic valve insufficiency.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Polyarteritis Nodosa (Option A): PAN is a medium-vessel necrotizing vasculitis, often associated with Hepatitis B, and involves organs like kidneys, skin, GI tract, nerves, but spares the lungs. It presents with fibrinoid necrosis, not granulomatous inflammation, and does not cause pulselessness or retinal hemorrhages.

Microscopic Polyangiitis (Option B): Affects small vessels, and presents with glomerulonephritis and pulmonary capillaritis. It is p-ANCA (MPO) positive and histologically shows pauci-immune necrotizing vasculitis without granulomas or giant cells. It does not affect large vessels or cause pulselessness.

Henoch-Schonlein Purpura-HSP (Option D): Now called IgA vasculitis, it is a small vessel vasculitis seen primarily in children, with:

  • Palpable purpura
  • Abdominal pain
  • Arthritis
  • Renal involvement
    Histology shows IgA immune complex deposition, not granulomatous inflammation or large vessel involvement.

choices.text: Microscopy shows fibrinoid necrosis in large arteries

questions.text: Which of the following is true about PAN?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • PAN is characterized by necrotizing immune complex inflammation of small- and medium-sized arteries.
  • It is marked by the destruction of arterial media and internal elastic lamella, resulting in aneurysmal nodules.
  • There is an association with hepatitis B viral infection in 30% of patients.
  • Clinical manifestations often include fever, weight loss, malaise, abdominal pain, headache, myalgia, and hypertension.
  • Polyarteritis nodosa is seen in the following sites:
    • Kidneys, with immune complex vasculitis in the arterioles and glomeruli; renal lesions, and hypertension cause most deaths from polyarteritis nodosa.
    • Coronary arteries, resulting in ischemic heart disease
    • Musculoskeletal system, resulting in myalgia, arthralgia, or arthritis
    • Gastrointestinal tract, manifesting as nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain
    • Central nervous system (CNS) or peripheral nervous system, the eye, or skin

questions.text: Cleft like space in atheromatous plaque mainly contains?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In histological sections of atherosclerotic plaques, cholesterol crystals are often seen as cleft-like empty spaces.

  • This occurs because cholesterol is dissolved during tissue processing, leaving behind sharp, needle-shaped voids (clefts) in the plaque.
  • These clefts are a hallmark of atheromatous (atherosclerotic) plaques, which are composed of:
    • Lipid core: containing cholesterol, cholesterol esters, and cell debris
    • Fibrous cap: made of smooth muscle cells and collagen
    • Inflammatory cells: including macrophages and T-cells
  • The cholesterol in the core is extracellular and derives from lipid-laden macrophages (foam cells) and necrotic debris.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Smooth muscle cells (Option A): These are found in the fibrous cap and media, contributing to plaque stability, but they do not form cleft-like spaces.

Fibrous tissue (Option B): This forms part of the fibrous cap and stabilizes the plaque, but again, it does not appear as clefts.

Macrophages (Option D): Present in the lipid core and shoulder region of the plaque, macrophages ingest lipids to become foam cells, but they do not form clefts. Instead, their lipid content contributes to the formation of cholesterol clefts when dissolved during processing.

questions.text: Atherosclerosis causes fibroblast plaque formation by injury to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Atherosclerosis begins with endothelial injury, which is the primary and initiating event in the development of atherosclerotic plaques. This injury triggers a cascade of pathological processes that lead to fibrofatty plaque formation.

Sequence of Events in Atherosclerosis:

  • Endothelial injury or dysfunction Caused by:
    • Hypertension
    • Hyperlipidemia (especially LDL)
    • Smoking
    • Diabetes
    • Turbulent blood flow
  • Increased endothelial permeability

Leads to entry of LDL into the intima.

  • Oxidation of LDL

Oxidized LDL is pro-inflammatory and chemotactic.

  • Monocyte adhesion and migration

Monocytes enter the intima, differentiate into macrophages, and engulf oxidized LDL to become foam cells.

  • Smooth muscle cell migration and proliferation

Smooth muscle cells move from the media to the intima and contribute to extracellular matrix production, including collagen.

  • Fibrous cap formation

The lesion eventually develops a fibrous cap made of collagen and smooth muscle cells, over a lipid core.

  • Thus, the initial endothelial injury is what initiates the entire atherosclerotic process, including fibroblast and smooth muscle cell activity.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Fibroblast (Option B): Fibroblasts are not the primary trigger of plaque formation. Their role in atherosclerosis is minor compared to that of smooth muscle cells and macrophages.

Macrophage (Option C): Macrophages are involved after endothelial injury. They contribute to foam cell formation and inflammation, but they are not the initiating factor.

Smooth muscle cells (Option D): These proliferate and synthesize collagen in the later stages, forming the fibrous cap, but again, they act in response to endothelial injury, not before it.

questions.text: Syphilitic aneurysm is seen most commonly in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Syphilitic aneurysm is a complication of tertiary (late) syphilis, caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum.

  • It results from chronic inflammation of the vasa vasorum (the small blood vessels supplying the aortic wall), leading to obliterative endarteritis.
  • This causes:
    • Ischemic injury to the media
    • Loss of elastic support
    • Weakening and dilation of the aortic wall
  • Ultimately resulting in a saccular aneurysm
  • The ascending thoracic aorta is the most common site involved in syphilitic aneurysms.
  • This is because the vasa vasorum are most prominent in the ascending aorta, making it most susceptible to damage.
  • Tree bark" appearance of the intima due to scarring and wrinkling
  • May cause:
    • Aortic insufficiency (by dilating the aortic root)
    • Compression of adjacent structures
    • Rupture

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Arch of aorta (Option B): Although adjacent to the ascending aorta, it is less commonly affected compared to the ascending portion.

Descending aorta (Option C): More commonly affected in atherosclerotic aneurysms, not syphilitic ones.

Abdominal aorta (Option D): This is the most common site for atherosclerotic aneurysms, especially below the renal arteries, but not for syphilitic aneurysms.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An aneurysm is an abnormal, localized dilatation of a blood vessel due to weakening of the vessel wall.

  • It may be caused by various pathological processes that compromise structural integrity, particularly of the tunica media.
  • Monckeberg's sclerosis:
    • This is medial calcific sclerosis, involving calcification of the tunica media of medium-sized arteries (especially radial and ulnar)
    • It does not compromise vessel wall strength, and does not cause aneurysm
    • Usually found incidentally on imaging in elderly patients
    • It does not lead to obstruction, weakening, or dilatation of the vessel
  • Causes of Aneurysm
    • Atherosclerosis
    • Hypertension
    • Tertiary syphilis
    • Trauma
    • Infections (Mycotic aneurysms)
    • Vasculitis (e.g., Takayasu arteritis, PAN, Giant cell arteritis)
    • Congenital connective tissue defects
    • Marfan syndrome
    • Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
    • Cystic medial degeneration

questions.text: Most common cause of dissecting hematoma is because of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypertension is the most common cause of aortic dissection (dissecting hematoma), especially in older adults, due to degenerative changes in the tunica media (cystic medial necrosis).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Marfan's (Option B): Important cause in young patients, especially involving ascending aorta, but less common overall than hypertension.

Iatrogenic (Option C): Can occur during procedures (e.g., catheterization or surgery), but is rare.

Kawasaki (Option D): Primarily affects children and causes coronary artery aneurysms, not aortic dissection.

questions.text: All are true about Kawasaki disease; except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kawasaki disease (KD) is a medium-vessel vasculitis that primarily affects children under 5 years of age.

  • It has a distinct set of clinical features, and the diagnostic criteria include:
    • Fever lasting more than 5 days (mandatory)
    • Plus at least 4 of the following 5:
      • Conjunctival injection (bilateral, non-purulent)
      • Oral mucosal changes (strawberry tongue, fissured lips)
      • Peripheral extremity changes (edema, erythema, later desquamation)
      • Polymorphous rash
      • Cervical lymphadenopathy (usually unilateral)
  • Kawasaki disease is typically associated with thrombocytosis, especially in the subacute phase.
  • Thrombocytopenia is not characteristic and may suggest an alternative diagnosis or complication like disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Desquamation rashes on trunk (Option B): Desquamation, particularly of the skin on the fingers and toes, is common in the convalescent phase. Truncal rash may occur early on, and peeling may extend there.

Fever (Option C): High-grade fever persisting for at least 5 days is a hallmark of the disease.

Conjunctival congestion (Option D): Bilateral non-suppurative conjunctival injection is a major diagnostic criterion.

questions.text: True about Takayasu is all; except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Takayasu arteritis is a large vessel granulomatous vasculitis that primarily affects the aorta and its major branches.

  • It is most commonly seen in young women, especially of Asian descent.
  • Takayasu arteritis involves large vessels, particularly the aorta and its major branches (e.g., subclavian, carotid arteries).
  • It does not primarily affect medium or small vessels.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Causes transmural granuloma (Option A):

True. Takayasu arteritis is a granulomatous inflammation that affects all layers (transmural) of the vessel wall, particularly the aorta and its branches.

Granulomatous vasculitis (Option B):

True. It is a classic example of granulomatous vasculitis, similar to giant cell arteritis but occurs in younger individuals.

Called aortoarteritis (Option D):

True. It is also referred to as "aortoarteritis" due to its predilection for the aorta and its branches.

questions.text: HSP is characterized by all; except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Henoch-Schonlein Purpura (HSP)-now more commonly called IgA vasculitis-is a small-vessel vasculitis characterized by IgA immune complex deposition, and typically affects children.

  • The classic clinical tetrad includes:
    • Palpable purpura (especially on lower extremities and buttocks)
    • Arthralgia/arthritis
    • Abdominal pain ± hematochezia
    • Renal involvement (IgA nephropathy-like glomerulonephritis)
  • HSP is a non-thrombocytopenic purpura.
  • Platelet count is normal in HSP, which helps differentiate it from other causes of purpura like ITP.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Glomerulonephritis (Option A): IgA deposition leads to renal involvement in HSP, manifesting as hematuria and sometimes proteinuria.

Hematochezia (Option B): Gastrointestinal bleeding due to vasculitis of the bowel wall is common and may present as hematochezia or melena

Palpable purpura (Option D): This is the hallmark skin manifestation of HSP, especially on the lower limbs.

questions.text: c-ANCA is positive in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wegener's Granulomatosis is a small to medium vessel necrotizing vasculitis that typically affects the upper respiratory tract, lower respiratory tract, and kidneys. It is strongly associated with c-ANCA (cytoplasmic-antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies), which target proteinase-3 (PR3) in neutrophils.

Key Clinical Features:

  • Chronic sinusitis, nasal ulcers, or bloody nasal discharge
  • Lung involvement: cough, hemoptysis, cavitating nodules
  • Renal involvement: rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
  • Systemic symptoms: fever, malaise, weight loss

Important Diagnostic Marker:

  • c-ANCA (anti-PR3): Highly specific for GPA/Wegener's
  • Biopsy shows: necrotizing granulomatous inflammation and vasculitis

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Microscopic Polyangiitis (Option A): This condition is also a necrotizing small-vessel vasculitis, commonly affecting kidneys and lungs. However, it lacks granulomatous inflammation and is associated with p-ANCA (anti-MPO), not c-ANCA.

Churg-Strauss Syndrome (Option C): Also known as Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA), it presents with asthma, eosinophilia, and granulomatous vasculitis. The typical antibody marker is p-ANCA (anti-MPO). c-ANCA is not characteristic.

Behcet's Syndrome (Option D): A non-ANCA-associated vasculitis, Behcet's is a variable vessel vasculitis characterized by recurrent oral/genital ulcers, uveitis, and skin lesions. It does not show ANCA positivity.

choices.text: Involves large to small sized areteries
Most commonly involved artery is abdominal aorta

questions.text: All is true about Giant cell arteritis; except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA), also known as Temporal Arteritis, is a granulomatous large-vessel vasculitis that primarily affects elderly individuals, especially women over 50 years old.

Key Features:

  • Vessel Involvement: Primarily affects branches of the carotid artery, especially the temporal artery
  • Histology: Granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells
  • Clinical Symptoms:
    • Temporal headache
    • Jaw claudication
    • Visual disturbances (due to ophthalmic artery involvement)
    • Constitutional symptoms (fever, fatigue)
  • Complication: Can lead to irreversible blindness if not treated early with corticosteroids
  • Lab Findings: Elevated ESR and CRP

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Involves large to small sized arteries (Option A): GCA primarily affects large arteries (e.g., temporal, ophthalmic, vertebral) but can extend to medium and small-sized arteries, especially their branches.

Granulomatous inflammation (Option B): Histopathology of GCA classically shows granulomatous inflammation with giant cells, often affecting the internal elastic lamina.

Segmental nature of the involvement (Option D): GCA exhibits skip lesions, meaning the inflammation is segmental, and a biopsy may miss the affected part if taken from an uninvolved area.

choices.text: Involves small and medium sized arteries and veins
75% cases are associated with ANCA positivity
Palpable purpura, ulcers and vesiculo bullous lesion
Unlikely to cause pulmonary renal syndrome

questions.text: Microscopic polyangiitis is characterized by the following features; except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Microscopic Polyangiitis is a necrotizing vasculitis affecting small vessels (arterioles, capillaries, venules) and sometimes medium-sized vessels. It is pauci-immune (minimal immune complex deposition) and is strongly associated with ANCA, most commonly p-ANCA (anti-MPO).

Key Clinical Features:

  • Systemic features: Fever, weight loss, arthralgia
  • Skin involvement: Palpable purpura, ulcers, vesiculobullous lesions
  • Renal involvement: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
  • Pulmonary involvement: Alveolar hemorrhage, leading to pulmonary-renal syndrome
  • Neurologic involvement: Mononeuritis multiplex

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Involves small and medium sized arteries and veins (Option A): MPA is primarily a small-vessel vasculitis, but it can also involve medium-sized arteries and veins, leading to multi-organ involvement.

75% cases are associated with ANCA positivity (Option B): About 75-90% of cases show ANCA positivity, most commonly p-ANCA (anti-MPO). This serologic marker is important for diagnosis and disease monitoring.

Palpable purpura, ulcers and vesiculo bullous lesion (Option C): These are common cutaneous manifestations of MPA due to leukocytoclastic vasculitis affecting dermal capillaries and venules.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about Kaposi sarcoma ?
a. Causative agent HHV 8
b. Can be Seen in depressed cell mediated immunity
c. Treatment is chemotherapy and surgery
d. Vascular tumor
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular neoplasm strongly associated with Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) infection. It is most frequently seen in settings of immunosuppression, especially HIV/AIDS. Multiple types of KS exist, including classic, endemic (African), iatrogenic (post-transplant), and epidemic (AIDS-related).

  1. Causative agent HHV-8 (Option A)

Kaposi sarcoma is caused by Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), also known as Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV). Presence of HHV-8 is essential for the development of this tumor.

  1. Can be seen in depressed cell-mediated immunity (Option B)

It is commonly seen in HIV-positive patients, organ transplant recipients, or patients on immunosuppressive therapy. The reduced T-cell-mediated immune surveillance allows HHV-8 to promote tumor growth.

  1. Treatment is chemotherapy and surgery (Option C)

Treatment depends on the type and extent of disease:

  • HAART (Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy) is essential in HIV-associated KS
  • Localized lesions may be treated with surgical excision, radiotherapy, or intralesional chemotherapy
  • Widespread or aggressive disease may require systemic chemotherapy (e.g., liposomal doxorubicin)
  1. Vascular tumor (Option D)

Kaposi sarcoma is a low-grade vascular tumor, composed of spindle cells and blood-filled vascular spaces. It often appears as red-purple plaques or nodules, especially on the skin, oral mucosa, and sometimes internal organs.

questions.text: Fish hook pattern of capillaries is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hemangiopericytoma is a rare vascular tumor thought to originate from pericytes (contractile cells surrounding capillaries and venules). It is now considered part of a spectrum with solitary fibrous tumors.

Histopathological Hallmark:

  • Fish hook or stag horn pattern of capillaries is the classic microscopic finding.
  • The tumor shows branching, thin-walled blood vessels resembling deer antlers or fish hooks surrounded by a cellular stroma.

Clinical Points:

  • Can occur in various locations including soft tissues, retroperitoneum, and meninges
  • Behavior ranges from benign to malignant
  • Treated by surgical excision, sometimes followed by radiotherapy

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Capillary hemangioma (Option A): This is a benign vascular tumor of infancy, composed of capillary-sized vessels. It shows tightly packed, thin-walled capillaries without the fish hook/stag horn vascular architecture.

Cavernous hemangioma (Option B): A benign lesion composed of dilated, blood-filled vascular spaces. Histology shows large cavernous vascular channels, not the characteristic fish hook pattern.

Angiosarcoma (Option C): A high-grade malignant vascular tumor, often seen in skin, breast, or liver. Histology shows anaplastic endothelial cells forming irregular vascular spaces, but it does not display the fish hook or stag horn pattern.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents with a rapidly enlarging, violaceous skin lesion on her left upper arm. She reports a history of chronic lymphedema in the same limb following a radical mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection for breast cancer 10 years ago. On examination, the lesion is nodular, irregular, and has areas of ulceration. A biopsy of the lesion reveals anaplastic endothelial cells forming irregular vascular channels. Which of the following is the most likely CD marker of the diagnosis?
CD marker of Angiosarcoma is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario describes angiosarcoma, a high-grade malignant vascular tumor. It often arises in the setting of chronic lymphedema (as seen in this patient post-mastectomy), a classic example of Stewart-Treves syndrome.

Immunohistochemistry in Angiosarcoma:

  • CD31 (also known as PECAM-1, platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule) is the most sensitive and specific marker for endothelial cells.
  • It is strongly expressed in angiosarcoma and is widely used to confirm vascular origin.
  • Additional endothelial markers: CD34, Factor VIII-related antigen (von Willebrand factor)

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

CD10 (Option A): Expressed in renal cell carcinoma, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, and some lymphomas. It is not a marker for vascular tumors.

CD19 (Option B): A B-cell marker, used in the diagnosis of B-cell lymphomas and leukemias. Not expressed in endothelial cells or angiosarcoma.

CD25 (Option C): The IL-2 receptor alpha chain, commonly expressed in T-cell leukemias/lymphomas, such as adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma. Not associated with vascular tumors

questions.text: A patient had a quarrel with his brother with heightened emotion and falls suddenly and died. Most likely cause of death in this case is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or "broken heart syndrome", is a transient cardiac condition often triggered by intense emotional or physical stress (e.g., a quarrel, loss of a loved one, or shock).

Key Features:

  • Common in postmenopausal women, but can occur in any adult under severe emotional stress
  • Sudden onset of chest pain or collapse, mimicking myocardial infarction
  • ECG may show ST-segment elevation or T wave inversion
  • Troponins may be mildly elevated
  • Coronary angiography shows no significant coronary artery obstruction
  • Echocardiography shows apical ballooning (resembling a Japanese octopus trap, "takotsubo")

Pathophysiology:

  • Believed to result from catecholamine surge (epinephrine/norepinephrine) leading to myocardial stunning
  • May cause sudden cardiac dysfunction, arrhythmias, or even cardiogenic shock or death

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (Option A): Characterized by fibrofatty replacement of the right ventricular myocardium, leading to arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death, especially in young athletes. However, it is not typically triggered by emotional stress and usually presents in younger individuals.

Dilated cardiomyopathy (Option C): A chronic condition with ventricular dilation and systolic dysfunction. It leads to progressive heart failure, not sudden death from emotional triggers.

Chronic ischemic cardiomyopathy (Option D): Occurs due to long-standing coronary artery disease and leads to heart failure. It is not acute and does not typically present with sudden death after emotional stress.
